div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hedeirab. Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah at call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: THE HEDJAZ RAILWAY
div.p: THE HEDJAZ RAILWAY

Much lias been written under this heading, the subject being one that appeals strongly to the student of the Near East ever fond of speculating os to the future position of Turkoy. The undertaking of the line was launched mainly for religious purposes, the subscriptions having, chiefly come froriii those interested in the pilgrimage to the Holy Places. To see Mecca and die is not always the ultimate wish of every good Mussulman, But to bav^been to the Holy City is to have proclaimed tho pilgrim as a devoted follower of the tenets of the Prophet. Anything, therefore, which makes tho undertaking of such a pilgrimage less arduous to the Faithful appeals to* the fervid followers of the founder of their religion.

The seriousness of the undertaking in tho past has been recognised by the fact that of thoso who start forth a large numbof never return to their homes. Every year death claims a large roll of victims among the intrepid pilgrims. Although to die whilst fulfilling such a holy mission; is, not such a lamentable end to earthly 'existence as to have deterred many from taking the risks, yet of late years there has boerf a tendency on.tho part of tho pilgrims themselves to 'appreciate the efforts made to improve their conditions of travel Thus an Increasing number of pilgrims, more especially from Egypt, takoudvantage of the facilities offored by the Mahmal, and so \expndtw20 benefiting;protection \expndtw0 offered by an escort of arm^ \strike fe\strike0 oo\strike fa\strike0 . How great an event - in the Mussulman world the completion of direct railway communication with the Holy City will ho.l A. comparatively safe and expeditious railway jotimey will take the place of thq present primitivo system of travelling by caravans with hardshipa incidental to a trek

wonder that under present ill* organized transport, thw worn and weary, often fall prey to marauding Bedouins, with scanty-fobd fcncffi precarious water supply from sources o'ften foul and contaminated, and large numbers either never seo the sacred city or afterwards pay the forfeit for their fortitude with their lives.

The fullest description of the line at present under construction from Damascus to Mecca which has as yet appeared is on account written by Auler Pasha*in a recent supple- mentary number of Petermans Mitteilungen." The total distance to be traversed has been estimated at 1,750 kilometres. The line has already reached Tebuk, 750 kilometres from Damascus. It is expected to be completed in 1913, or .1910 iHhe sections between Jeddah and Mecca and Mecca and Medina are simultaneously put in hand. One of the greatest obstacles has been the carriage of materials, which had, at its inception, to be brought entirely by the French lino from Boy rout viA Damascus toEi Mexeirib in the valley of tho Nahr Yarmuk, an eastern tributary of tho Jordan. Attempts to purchase the French line failed, and.Turkey was obliged to conatrucb a parallel lino to Deraah, just west of El Mezeirib. The British concession from Haifa to Da\strike m\strike0 a\strike scu\strike0 s was, however, purchased, and the lino completed to Der to tho necessity of making a stone briage over tho Jordan, .find of constructing tunnels and aqueduct*, this has formed, up terth^ present, tho most expensive and laborious section of the route.

Even with Hqifa as a base of operations for materials, land carriage is found * very ex* pensive, as from Maaq onifAnis to the present terminusv all water as well as food' has to bo brought by raii. Hence the late attempt to extend tho Turkish spTierO in'the neighbourhood. of can be explained as much by economic as political reasons, since easy access from the Red Sea to tho main lino' would materially expedite the work. As it seems, moreover, to have already eofiaidefably diminished the expenses and hardships involved in reaching Mecca from the nyrth it is probable that there will bo no difficulty, in obtaining tho money necessary to "'compl'ote the work, though beyond Moan it will bo solely a pilgrim route.

div.head: DRUSES AND BEDOUINS.
div.p: A SERIOUS CONFLICT.

Severe fighting took place at the end of Ootober between the Druses and the Walod Aly Bedouins within twenty miles of Damas-ons. Nearly 10,000 men were engaged in the oonfliot, resulting in the complete viotory of the Druse force. A great number of ameers aud sheikhs of the Waled Ali- were killed and an im* mense amount of booty was taken by the visitors. Ur fortunately, the plunder of some Damascus merchants who were in the Bedouin camp has led to strained relations between Damaoe ueand the Hauran, and till recently trade relations were almost entirely suspended.

div.head: BRIGAND WAR IN MAOBDON.
div.p: A telegram arrived to-day at Alexandria from A\ Athens relating a serious affray between Turkish troops and a Bulgar band, thirty-six strong, at S'rumnitzv The Komitadjia were wiped oot after a fierce fight, six alone escaping. The Turks lost six men. The leader of the band was an ex-officer of the Bulgarian Army.

div.head: MAAN-AKABA TELEGRAPH.
div.p: The Turkish Government has erected a telegraph line between Maan aud Akaba, the former being one of the Hedjaz Railway étalions, and sentinels have been posted to guard the line. According to "Al-Ahram," large quantities of corn and barley are being imported into the Hedjsz from 8yria by way of Akaba.

div.head: MR. ROBERTSON, M. P.
div.p: In connection with Mr. Robertson's visit, "À1 Ahram" remarks :—Mr. RobortaoD, M.P., who is so well-known to all the Egyptians, has visited A1 Azhar University and some of the native quarters in Cairo. A number of natives have been paying him visits and have gone to welcome him. Soon, no doubt, Mr. Robertson will see more of the natives' attitude than he expeoted, because they bear the remembrance in their miods of the beneficent deads which this visitor to Bjypt has done in order to defend the interests ot the Egyptians iu the British Parliament and they are expectant of many benefits through his instrumentality.

div.head: PRESS POLEMICS.
div.p: A vigorous campaign is being waged between "L'Egypte" and "Al Moayad." Opening with the question of secular versus religious instruction, on which M. Colrat (who avows himself "libre-penseur") naturally took a different line from his orthodox Modem critics, it ended in the nnfortnnate publication by oar French contemporary of a .passage in which the Prophet was mentioned in a manner that could not fail to shook any Moslem. "Al-Moayad" has published au open letter to Idris Bey Ragheb pointing out the passage referred to and remarking that it is strange indeed that a paper owned by an Egyptian should publish remarks that must wound every right-minded Egyptian Moslem.

div.head: MUNICIPALITY AND PRESS.
div.p: A correspondent writes :—

I am sorry to have to acknowledge that the Press bas no right to assist at the meetings of the Municipal Commission. The mucioipal decree says that the publio oannot be admitted. Some belligerent editors pretend that the publio and the Press are two absolutely different enti* ties. But in the anôté ministeriel it dearly says that communications of the meetings of the MunioipOl Commission may be given to the Press. This provision 'surely implies that the Press ia included in the term "publio." It is true that this law was made no less than sixteen years ago, when perhaps the Government was amply justified in making those restrictions. Of late years, however (I say it in all seriousness), the Press has made Buoh giant strideB in advanoe that at leaH certain journals ought to be admitted to bore their wretohed reportera with the foor hours' purgatory once a week of listening to the oratory of the municipal ooDucillors.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.8. Creole Prince, with passengers and general cargo from Antwerp and London, viil Malta, arrived at Alexandria on the 4th inst. The Moss liner Soti sailed from Liverpool yesterday afternoon, and is due here about the 18th inst, with passengers, mails and general cargo. Tbe S.S. Persian Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left Malta on the 4th inst, and is due at Alexandria on Tuesday.

div.head: INTERESTING FINDS.
div.p: THE IBRAHIMIEH EXCAVATIONS

The discoveries which have been made by the chief eanuoh of H.H. the Khedive at Ibrahimich are very nameroos. Besides the vases, which we mentioned yesterday, they include a number of terra-cotta figures, alabaster vases for perfumes, and funerary statues, often with inscriptions. The excavations are being oonduoîel on the site of an old neoropolis. Inscriptions have been disooverei of many of the persona boriedor cremated there. Many of these come from Crete, Thessaly, Athena, and SidoD, and show that'the inhabitants of ancient Alexandria came from all parts of the Eastern Mediterranean. The finds up to date prove that the necropolis dates from 300 to 200 bo. The vases discovered are known in arch» ology as ths vases oFGnathia, as a great nom-ber hive been found in that towo of Apulia, fie modern Fosano. , Arobædogists have endeavoured to prove that these beautifully modelé vases had their origin at Tarantnm* But since so many of these vases have of lato been found at Alexandria, it is possible that the real origin must be looked for hore,and not in Southern Italy. The vases have charming reliefs ^executed in the béât style of Hellenistio Art For some time past inscriptions, evidently from a Christian neoropolis of the sixth oentury.of our era, have been found at Dekho-leb, near Mex. Messrs. Almsgia have quarries close by and last week nine sphinxes were found there They have been taken to the Alexandria Museum. The Museum intends conducting excavations there. The origin of these sphinxes and how they came to be there are a mystery. The visitors to tho Musoom during the past year numbered 5,076, to Pompey's Pillar 3,147, and to Korn ol Shougafah 5,037. The visitors to the Maseum show an inorease of 2,180, to the Pillar of 852, and Kom-el Shoogafah of 521 over tho total for 1905.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA TRAMWAY CO.
div.p: The board of directors of the Aîoxandria Tramway Company have seleoted Mr. John Chini as a director, in the place of the late Mr. Pericles Glymenopoulo. Tho Alexandria Municipality want the company to place their line in the oentre of the new boulevard along Ihe quay, which would be two metres lower tban the present level of the railway. The company has agreed to lower the permanent way on the stipulation that the Manioipa'ity does all the earthwork, „ The new position of the line underneath Ihe old line in some places necessitates considerable engineering difficulties to avoid traffic not being stopped while the work is in' progress. Several temporary lines have to bo laid in consequence. Tho new line will be fenoed in on both Aides after Chatby bridge, with level ororsingB at fixed points. Tbe work will take several months to complete.

div.p: A movemont is on foot among the members of tho Greek Orthodox community at Alexandria to make a pilgrimage to Jerusalem at the Greek Easter. They will he lodged at the Orthodox pilgrims' houce wbiob the Patriaroh Damiano erected there last year.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL SPORTING CLUB.
div.p: YESTERDAY'S GYMKHANA.

Though the Gymkhana yesterday at Ghezireh was timed to oommence at 2.80 there were hot few people present at that hour, and it'was nearly three o'clock before the first ovont was run. There is always far leas formality about a Gymkhana than a race meeting, and the variety of the events all' make for greater sociability among the onlookers, many of whem are called upon to render assist-anoe in the various competitions, etc., so that even if tbe'races lag somewhat in the running there is plenty of entertainment to be had in watching the preliminaries and arrangements.

The band of the 2nd Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliera provided mosio during the intervals from its new position opposite the stand, and the usual tea tables were surrounded by the usual orowd towards the end of the afternoon,, and expressions of satisfaction were heard on every side that the aoouatomed tea tickets were again in force, while in respeot of tho meal itself there is a marked improvement in the entertainment offered in comparison to that of former years. Albeit people were somewhat dilatory in arriving, nearly all the aoenstomed habitués were on the spot later on, and so many new-oomers were present that any detailed list beoomes difficult.

This season is doubtless going to be a reoord one as far as the good looks of the gentler box are concerned ; and many of those who poaod as belles last winter are having to content themselves with other consolations this year. No prettier groap could be found than that composed of the two elder Miss Andereona as they sat near little Miss Nungovich on the steps of the stand. Tbe two sisters were in bine and heliotrope mnslinp, and were wearing large picturesque hats wreathed about with enormous ostrich feathers. Tin coquettish bat with its orimeon roses and long floating veil worn by Miss Nungovich were a perfect setting for her piquant face and lovely eyes ; and the brilliant straps of oriental embroidery which trimmed her long cloak were in perfeot keeping with her colouring. Mrs, Leverioh and her daughter, the latter in white olotb, were sitting with Mrs. Gork and her two daughters, both of whom looking very fresh and charming in their pretty frocks of pale blue and pale green doth. Lady Muriel Beckwith looked very well ia grey relieved with black, and a pretty hat trimmed,; with silvery grapes. Both Lady Rogers and Mrs. Bullock were weariug'suits of black and white cheok, the latter'a being of the small smooth variety, but both ot them trimmed with narrow strappings of blaok. Lady Hemmiog was in white, while Miss Hemming wore a pale bine cloth frook and a large black hat with white feather. Mrs. Hutson was exquisitely neat bb usual in a well-fitting skirt and short bolero of white with narrow strides and pipings of dark blue, her hat bearing a bunch of green corn as trimming. Mrs. Rome was in white with a pretty crumpled velvet toque of rose, and Mrs. Gordon also wore a rose-oolonrpd toque and scarf with her *hite suit. The Misses Cole were in lawn coats and skirts with ooloured blouses and scarf», and Mrs. Kershaw was wearing a suit of somewhat the same oolouring with mooh brud and heavy embroidery upon it. Mrs. Hunter, who brought her handtome little sou with her, was wearing a short ooat of white fur; and Mrs. Herbert had a long white boa over her neat frook of navy blue. Mrs. Rome also bronght her little son and daughter and spent all the afternoon in their society, much to their enjoyment. Co on teas Bernsdorff was present with her daughter, and Mr. and Mrs. Iddings had also brought their daughter with them. Mrs. Carey, in'a very pretty gown of black, was accompanied by her two slender daughters, the one in white and the other in heliotrope. Miss Bnllook wore a very boocmiog hat of blue wiUf a white frook, and Mias Blythe was wearing a heliotrope talero and skirt with a handsome dark fox boa. Mrs* Wilson was in a tightly fitting ooat and skirt oi white serge and a very beoomtng hat of blue, and Miss Rees was also in white, touches of pale bine on the long coat corresponding in oolonr with the hat Bhe wore. Mrs. Gillaon was in grey with a black hat. Mrs. Sohreibet was in a tailor made suit that showed grey in the distance, bat might have been a black and white oheck. Miss Fearon wore a blue and white cheque with rovers and oufis of blue Mis. Wilding was in heliotrope—a dress of tbo empire persuasion—worn with a loDg white boa. Mrs, Saunders was in a jaunty little suit of pale fawn with a roee coloured tcqoe ornamented with the Qiual bunch of "Paradis." Amongst the other ladies present, spice forbidding a mention of the pretty frocks they wore, were Mrs. Phillips, Mies Coxon, Mrs. Andersou and her youngest daughter, Mrs. Wynne, Mrs. Buffers, Mrs. Humphrey, Mrs. Joseph, Miss Simpson, Miss MoKillyooddy, eta Time and space al-io forbid a mention of the sterner sex who graced the assembly.

Soffioe it to add that all the male relatives of the aforementioned ladies were in their neighbourhood, in addition to all those unattaohed and forlorn baohelors whose professions or relaxations tie them here in Cairo.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince and Princess Stirrberg, after their return from the Nile trip on board the daha-beab Mena, have been staying at Shepheard's for a fortnight, and left yesterday for Berlin.
Baron Edmond do Rothschild is staying at the Savoy Hotel.
Sir Ernest Caseel is expeoted to arrive in Cairo in a week.

Sir Wm.'and Lady Geary arrived at Alex -andrra yesterday by the S.S. Ismailia. Sir William, who is an authority on law matters, was called to the Bar at the Inner Temple in 1884 and from 1895-97 was Attorney General at Aoora, on the Gold Coast. He owns abou t 2,800 aore^in Mid-Kent, Dear Tunbridge, and has published several legal works.

Mr. McMillan, the American traveller, ao oompanied by his wife and a large party, has arrived at Shepheard's. Mr. MoMillan is one ot the most successful lion hunters, and his wife is no less daring a shot.
M. Carlo Rosetti, the new Italian Consul for Khartoum, is expeoted to arrive io Cairo shortly.

M. Louis Bertrand, the well known French author, has just arrived in Egypt from Jerusalem on the conclusion of the jourooy he undertook for the "Rivue des Diux Mondes," which will publish his impressions under the title of "The Orient." M. Bertrand is leaving for Paris shortly.

M. Eastache Glymenopoulgs, brother to the late banker, has contested i. 4 disposal made by the Hellenic Consalar Court of Alexandria of the estate of the deceased. He has interested himself in behalf of the daughter of the late M. Glymeuopoulo. He has left for. Athens to lodge his protest with tbe Court of Probate there.
The Grecia Lodge of Cairo gave their ann ual installation banquet at the Savoy Hotel, wh en Mr. Sbarman was installed. Forty-eight persons sat down to dinner, which was served in the salle dos fêtes.

Another big banquet was givenat the Savoy Hotel yesterday evening by the medical studouta. Amongst those present werq ; Dr. Keatingp, Dr. Ibrahim Pasha Hassan, Dr. Shookry Bey, Dr. Nolan, Dr. Hobson, Dr. Madden, Dr. Fisher, Dr. Beddoe, Capt. Brakenridge, Dr. Bitter, Dr. ElliotSmith, Dr. Llewelyn Phillip, etc.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE.
div.p: "MEFISTOFELE."

We will oonfeu that we have (to use a cant phrase) but a very small modicum of use for this pieoe, which we heard twice two years ago In Cairo, and oarriod away on each occasion an impression of little more than noise. Here, from the technical point of view; the performance was infinitely superior. The prologue ia of course the "résiatanoe" of a ] n, ytiioh is theuoefortb utterly lacking' in any notent distinction ; and even herq the libretto is exasperatingly feeble. It is bard to derive any pleasure from cherubim who continually sing "La danza in angelica spire si gira si gire si girai" when the curtain ia ?down, and one sees nothings Signor JDario^ Iras here .and throughout in greatvoioeX-nottainly thé beat aotor on the^ atagv AtfeiHthoprologue the opera steadily goe«V^rajtad?.to worüe. -The garden soene is a treyc- f s vGojanod, though all four performers aotdd ahd 'c^g1 well in It. Bat the height of absardi^^ re^ohed in the "notte del Sabba." At the ' bacIcVof the ratage blue and pink eleotrio fights dre'ewung to and fro on strings. In the midst is a high square platform, densely- packed with gentlemen frantically gesticulating like Labour members iu Hyde Park, and in the foreground a bevy of modt attractive ladies trip and skip batkwards and forwards and round and round so agreeably, that onr neighbouring stall remarked "II parait qu'on est très bien là bas." Margherita, in spite of ber tremolo, scored a distinct success in her death socne, to reappear shortly, bewitcbiDgly enough, in the Sabba olassioo. Here, by the river Peneos, our worst fears were realised. The soenery indeed was accurate enough : Dorio temp'es—plenty of . them—complete with triglyphr, and all that our Laoonian taste demanded.; bat the ohorns and ballet wore tight stays, to a woman; which practice, though perhaps inevitable in a ballet, yet destroys fo* onéb more CEln $uy other fault, the smallest illusion of Greece. Faust showed to advantage here, though he ia a little apt to go out of tune. The epilogue, with its repetition of the opening theme, was finely done, but it is too long and too loud. Orchestra and chorus are still improving ; Sig. Gianoli I may be congratulated on a fine performance of a very indifferent opera.

div.head: "INVESTMENTS."
div.p:
"Investments" introduces, in an entirely original manner, new and important methods for the employment of and the means of obtaining capital. Among the
SPECIALLY CONTRIBUTED ARTICLES
are "Stock Markets and How to Profit by Them"; "Theory of Successful Speculation"; "How to start an Account" ; "The Advantages of 'Call Options'"; "Contangoing Mining and Industrial Securities" ; "How to Invest in Mines"; "American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees"; "The Purchase of Investment Securities by Instalments" ; "General Principles for Investors" ; "Rules for Investors in Mines"; "General Principles for Speculators"; "Stock Exchange Terms," being a glossary for Market Operators; "Stock Exchange Parlance"; "Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money," and "Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities."
"Investments" (148 pages) sent Post Free on mentioning "Egyptian Gazette."

div.head: CONTRATS, (11h.55 a.m.)
div.p: Cours de la Bourse de Minet-el-Bassal
REMARQUES
Cotons: Nouvelle récolte.—Le novembre a ouvert à 14 15/16 sous l'impression de la clôture d'Amérique et ne tarde même pas à fléchir à 14 7/8, mais il se raffermit de nouveau. Affaires claisemées.
Récolte actuelle. —Juillet a débuté à 14 5/16 et reste soutenu. Marché peu animé.
Grains de coton: Nouvelle récolte.— Sans affaires importante; quand même les cours sont bien tenus.
Récolte actuelle.—Juillet a obtenu P.T. 58 ¾ à l'ouverture.
Fèves-Saidi: Nouvelle récolte.—Marché nul.

div.head: CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN
div.p: Capital 12,500,000 Francs entièrement verses. — Agence d'Alexandrie, 14, Rue Stamboul.

LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN fait toutes opérations de Banque, notamment: Escompte d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'etranger. Avance sur titres.—Garde de titres.—Depots de fonds a vue et à échéance fixe avec intérêts aux taux suivants: 2 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts de 6 mois, 3 0/0 pour dépôts d'un an, 3 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts au délà d'un an. — LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN reçoit des Marchandises en consignation pour la vente et fait des Avances sur Cotons, Grains et autres marchandises. — 28337-10-8-907

div.head: NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT.
div.p: Capital: £3,000,000. RESERVE (Environ) : £1,340,000. MR. F. T. ROWLATT, Governor

Siège Social au Caire, Succursale à Alexandria, Agence à Assiout, Assuoan, Benha, Beni-Suef, Chibin el Kom, Damanhour, Fayoum, Khartoum, Kéneh, Mansourah, Minieh, Port-Said, Suakin, Sohag, Tantah, Zagazig, Mouski (Caire) et Londres (4 et 5, King William Street). La National Bank of Egypt reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. Elle s'occupe de l'achat et de la vente d'effets sur l'Etranger, de l'escompte, ainsi que de toutes opérations de Banque. 31-12-906

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs au sud de l'ancien cimetière israélite jusqu'au fort el Nahas.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 15.
Le cahier des charges est déposé an Bureau de la Voirie où il peut-être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 18 courant.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même jour à 5h.p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 18 courant à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur.
(signé) W.P. Chataway.
Alexandrie, le 7 juillet 1905.

div.head:
Dr. Le Clerc's
Pills for the Liver & Kidneys
div.p: are an unfailing and reliable remedy for diseases of these important organs, gout, rheumatism, gravel pains in the back and kindred ailments (acquired or constitutional). Sold by principal Chemists, not in loose quantities, but only in boxes, price 2s. 3d bearing the British Government Stamp with the words "Eugene Le Clerc" impressed thereon to protect the public from fraud.
Dr. Le Clerc's Soap.

Medical, antiseptic, used and recommended by eminent dermatoligists in the treatment of ecsema, lepers, psoriasis, ulcerations, skin eruptions, itching and irritating skin humours, baby rashes, etc., also a prophylactic against the risk of contracting disease and infectionus disorders generally. Its healing properties greatly minimize the inconveniences of shaving in cases of pimples, spots, In Tablets price 1/- sold by Max Fischer Alexandria.
